flavor is fruity, slightly citrussy, slightly tart, quite refreshing.

20110619  750ml from State Line, I believe.  Had bought six of these when it came out, and this is the last of them.  The deep orange-gold beer is lightly hazed with tall, lasting, creamy off-white head of large, building foam.  Aroma is spicy and very lemony, sourdough, Bretty botanicals,coriander.  Im sorry to see I hadnt rated this when fresher, because its quite a bit different now that its older.  Not at all suffering from age, the stuff is delicious, dry, and typically refreshing as are so many of the JP brews, but when it was younger there was a certain squashy undertone and light sweetness, but it seems to have perhaps fermented away now.  There is still a soft retronasal note that reminds me of spicy hot cocoa, the chili pepperiness of that subdued from how I recall it (not spicy, but verdent).  Nonetheless, theres nothing wrong with this, and Ill be keeping an eye out for some clearance prices on these bottles now that its so old.  Rating of 4.0 based on the run of bottles Ive had, though this one would probably only tally a 3.6 or so.

THOUGHTS: Rather sour. I dont really see the point of making a pumpkin beer that barely, if at all, tastes or smells like pumpkin or pumpkin pie spices. Dont get me wrong, it was a great beer, but its not really a pumpkin beer and should probably be put in the sour/wild ale category. It was similar in flavor and aroma to other Jolly Pumpkin beers, but it was much lighter in the flavor department. It had some of the best head and lacing Ive ever seen in a beer.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a hazy, medium, brownish orange with a large to huge, creamy, off-white head that diminished very slowly and kept a decent sheet that left excellent lacing that was thick and clingy. The aroma had apple, wood, sour apple, tons of sour fruit, spices and a little cocoa right at the end. The initial flavor was slightly sweet, light to moderately acidic and moderate to heavily sour; while the finish was moderate to rather acidic and heavily to nearly harshly sour with a long duration. There was sour apple, some spices, slight hints of pumpkin and cocoa, more sour fruit, dusty yeast and sour grapes.

750 ml bottle, batch #617, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 5.9%. Hazy deep golden to amber colour, large white head.  Strong sweetish aroma of marmalade, cider apples, oak, farmhouse, vinegar and pickled pumpkin. The flavour is sour / acidic with notes of vinegar and pickled pumpkin. Not my cup of tea.

This bier has an awesome label.  The lit pumpkins, the haunted "parcela" of pumpkin patch, the silhouetted scarecrows and trees.  AWESOME!  The bier itself, poured from a 750ml bottle, is a little less awesome.  Mostly I taste sour.  Not a mouth-puckering super sour, but a lower-middle range sour that your palate gets used to after 4 or 5 sips.  Then the malty, cacao taste comes through very delicately----I wish there was some more cacao, but its adequate.  Ah hell, its hard for me to dislike craft biers that have effort put into them so #1 Pumpkin Ale gets an above average score anyhow.  This bier is too expensive for me to buy again, but hey, Im glad I tried it at least.

Smell -Very little pumpkin and more sourness than anything.

Taste - The firs taste the pumpkin is great and works well with the sourness. After that, I find the sour overtakes the pumpkin and is the star of the show. Its not bad but id prefer the pumpkin to last the entire glass.

This was isnt bad at all and offers something familiar to Jolly Pumpkins fans.

Bottle (Batch 617) at Dæmningen 37 - shared with Mette, Karen & Henning. Cloudy amber - white head. Sourish notes. Wooden dryness. Light spicy. Milkey notes. Dryness. Cocoa notes. Nice bretty. Peppery. Sparkling. Ok.

Bottled. Murky orange coloured. Dense light beige head. Aroma of pumpkin, grape, light spice, vague cocoa, fruits and sweetness. Flavour of citrus, cocoa, fruits, grape. Medium to full bodied. Has a grapy and light sour end. Quite refreshing, and the pumpkin isnt ruining everything in the beer, which it tend to do in other examples of the "style".

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2012 Bottle. Slight hazy golden with medium off-white head. Aroma is malt, brett, fruit, hop and spices. Flavour is malt, brett, caramel, little tart, fruit, spices, little bitter, little acid and a little pumpkin.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of sour bret, pumpkin, cinnamon, ginger bread and some earthy cheese.  Medium orange hue with an off-white head that left some lace and fully diminished.  Flavor is medium sweet and bitter.  Palate is medium bodied and oily average with a short sour and tart finish.  Overall a wonderful pumpkin brew that I bet just needed age to bring out this wonderful sour aroma and taste.  Loved it.

Bottle at yespr.
Hazy orange coloured with a medium sized off-white head.
Fruity aroma of caramel, brett and berries.
Fruity flavour of berries with notes of brett and acidic notes.
Fruity finish.
Bottled.  An amber beer with a huge orangey head. The aroma has notes of straw, malt, and caramel. The flavor is sweet  wood,  straw , malt, and lemon, leading to a bitter finish.
75 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is fruity and slight citric. Spiced and slight herbal hoppy. Smooth wineous and fruity. Bitter and herbal to citric finish.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a cloudy golden with a lacing white head. Tart, fruity nose, some Brett but only a discreet note of cinnamon. Medium body, very soft mouthfeel, tart fruity notes, a little dry sulphur with a touch of Brett. Slightly tart. A different but very pleasant Pumpkin beer. 190511

Ive read a bunch of reviews before I posted this because I thought I might have gotten an infected bottle. Seems there are two types of reviews of this beer. Those that say the pumpkin/spices were strong and those who couldnt detect any. I fall in the latter. This is a great beer, but I didnt pick up any pumpkin or spices. Sour vinegary aroma. Pour was a medium hazy orange with a one finger white head. Taste was great. Strong vinegar, sour apple and and yeast fill the mouth. Nice strong biting carbonation. Mouth is dry and tart after the swallow. As the beer warms can pick up some cinnamon and allspice but very faint. Nice!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Beautiful cloudy shade or orange, with reddish tint. Huge white head that leaves a coat of foam on the glass as it slowly recedes. Big pumpkin spice aroma, mostly ginger and cinnamon, and a definite aroma of funky oak. A little bit of chocolate, just a tiny bit. Smells like I could of had chocolate drink in my glass and didnt wash before I poured this in. Very tart on the front of my tongue, with a sourness that washes the rest of my mouth. The spices are really muted in the taste, but the ginger is definitely still there. The sourness stays in the mouth for a bit after drinking, along with a slight lingering of the spices. Awesome beer.
Bottle thanks to Pailhead. Pours orange. Overcarbonated white head. Nose/taste of pumpkin, Brett, spice and yeast. Slightly spicy and even more slightly tart.
Batch 610 pours hazy orange with a thin white head. Aroma is sour, wood, and light spice. Flavor brings out a little funky pumpkin, spices, earthy, and a dry finish.

750 ml bottle, batch 611, bottled 8/18/2010.  Served in a pint glass, the brew pours a hazy orange/amber color with a 2 inch frothy off-white head theat stayed around a long time.  Theres also a decent amount of lacing.  Well, I dont smell any pumpkin in this beer.  It smells like tart apples, funk, lemon peel, and some nutmeg (which I dont notice until after the beer has been opened for a while).  Taste is just like the aroma, its mostly sour and funky until the beer has warmed up more and then the pumpkin spices are a little bit noticable.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, and it has high but soft carbonation which helps makes this easy to drink.  Overall I think its a good beer, even though its pricey at $12.99 a bottle.  Maybe I should try this fresher next time, even though I liked it just fine with some age on it.

Pours a clear golden amber with a white head, medium to low cabonation, good head retention, plenty of sediment at the bottom.  Strong pumpkin aroma and fall spices, nutmeg, allspice, slight citrus.  Taste is lightly tart and sweet.  Somewhat sticky texture, nice body, average carbonation, long finish.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a cloudy orange color with a small, off-white head.  The nose carries some tell-tale Jolly Pumpkin notes of brett and oak.  The pumpkin is there but it seems almost veiled.  The flavor has some light citrus notes, a light pumpkin (like mousse without the sweetness), brett, oak, and some coriander.  Light in body with soft carbonation leading to a lingering bretty finish.  A different and enjoyable take on a pumpkin ale.
Pumpkin color, and cloudy. Aroma and taste were Brett funk, and spice. I couldnt catch pumpkin in either aroma or taste. Medium body and head.
Bottle:  Pours golden with a small fizzy head.  Typical Jolly Pumpkin sour aroma.  Sour and small spicy flavor.  Good.

Cloudy orange, thin ring of foam. Nicely tart, sour aroma - almost like a geuzue (however you spell it). Nice lemon and cherry, with subtle hints of cinnamon and spice.  Some oaky notes, too. Lingering aftertaste. Good Stuff.

I wish the oak barrels werent so emphasized in its taste. I know thats Jollys calling card but it diminishes any compliments the cocoa could provide the pumpkin, and vice versa. The spices were mellow. The head was minimal. The lacing seemed to linger moreso than most JP brews. Completely drinkable and easily a session beer, had the barrels not been the most pronounced flavor. Nonetheless it is a superior beer to pair with Autumn/winter fare. Id prefer the former, though.

Bottle.  So Im rating 200 for this beer.  Nice!  Ive been wanting to try it for a while and finally the snow has pushed me to giving up on waiting any longer.  Its been quite a winter!  Pours a lovely orange with a huge fluffy head that leaves pillowy lacing all over the sides of the glass and on the surface of the beer.  Aromas have a nice pucker to them with a bit of apple cider, some sort of odd cinnamon type spicing (almost like a very faint and sour pumpkin pie, but that might just be suggestive from the name.)  Flavor is just right.  A nice sour apple dominant backbone with little side-currents of pie spice.  My only regret on this one is that it seems a bit watery at times... the flavor is full, but it doesnt stick around on the palate for long.  After a few ephemeral seconds, it heads off down the road.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
On tap at Churchky.

Pours a really nice hazy copper-orange with an off white head. Decent amount of lace on the way down. Nose brings definite notes of pumpkin along with some oak and a bit of earth. Some funk but not too much. Taste brings some light pumpkin flavor and slight sourness. Mostly earth and oak along with accompanying funk. Feel is light and dry. Drinks quite well and one of the better and most unique pumpkin beers out there.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-14-2010

Sample at Tasting Panel #1. 650ml bottle. Pours a cloudy gold with a small, creamy, white head. Aroma is earthy and woody with an acidic back bone. Flavour is fairly sour and I do pick up just a touch of pumpkin. Finishes tart, coarse and bone-dry. Decent, but pumpkin beers just arent my thing.

Great hazy orange/copper coloured body with a rusty bronze touch and a thin tan head. Aroma of sour grapes (lovely brettenoymics), light cherries, yeast, coriander seed and a touch of of piney hops - no cocoa at all to me. Medium-bodied; Slightly sweet, slightly sour flavour at first with a touch of the yeast, some light spices and a deep almost spicey/hot finish and palate. Aftertaste shows more sour and sweet notes than anything else - but this is very welcome indeed. Overall, another great beer in the style of Jolly Pumpkin - noticeable immediately as one of their beers. A great beer to try and a nice take on the style! I sampled this 75 cL bottle purchased from Discount Drinks in Wyandotte, Michigan on 16-January-2011 sampled at home in Washington on 13-February-2011.
750mL bottle, pours orange with a white head. Aroma of pumpkin, coriander and a little more orange-like fruit. Flavour of sour pumpkin, citrus, and a sour tang on the finish. Decent.

750 ml bottle poured a clear orange amber with a large lasting ivory head and good lacing. Aromas of allspice, cinnamon, clove carmel, light pumpkin and light sour citrus. Palate was ligt bodied and crisp with a dry lightly tart finish. Flavors of clove, cinnamon, cacao and light pumpkin with a crisp dry lightly tart lingering spiced finiush.

Pours a pillowy four finger off-white head that fades very slowly leaving a good lace. Cloudy amber color with a ton of yeast left in bottle. Good carbonation and medium bodied.  Nose is tart spices and flavor is tart, spicy with some pumpkin, like a mellow farmhouse ale - not the usual pumpkin pie ale. Beyond expensive at $18.50 for a 750ml bottle from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, ME. Batch 610, bottled 8-20-2010.

Poured orange with a big pillow of  white head. Aroma of bread, funk, spice,and a touch of ripe pumpkin. Taste sour, spices, funky bready, witha small back taste of pumpkin. Good beer overall rather interesting. Thanks to JSPrime for the share.

Nice orange color with a MASSIVE layer of foamy white head composed of many bubbles of various sizes.

Aroma is very appealing - some funky and spicy notes dominate.  Surprisingly, the flavor is much more reserved - not nearly as wild as I was hoping - basically just a much more mild version of the aroma.

Mouthfeel is fine - bubbly but with a certain smooth quality to it.  Drinkability is good.

Overall this is a quality beer, but I was definitely a bit underwhelmed.

Batch 610. Bottled On: 8/13/10.

Appearance: Pours a nearly clear, coppery body with a very tall, wispy, near-white head.

Smell: Lightly bready barley, maybe a sprinkling of wheat and hewn hay, infused with a note of oak barrels and hints of tartish green apples and shaved sour lemons. Any scents of pumpkin or spice certainly come across last and least appreciable.

Taste: Mild bready maltiness coupled with very mellow, very subtle spices and a nudge of lactic lemon. Staunchly dry throughout, with nearly no sweetness cross the tongue. Placid oak wood and faint earthiness midway. A sip of juiced Granny Smith apples rolls out a growing tartness (though never very much) on the back half with a sustained lactic touch. Occasionally, I perceive a vague vegetal, squashy tone, but I fear thats only because Im looking long and hard for it. Gentle tartness on the rather dry finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-high carbonation.

Drinkability: Those grumbling for ever less pumpkin and less spice character should consider giving this one a try, as both are virtually absent, at least in Batch 610. As always, its another weird, wild ride from Jolly Pumpkin.

On tap at Michael Symons B-Spot: Cloudy, deep golden. Baby powder, citrus, Brett, chocolate, funky spice. slick mouth feel, tart acidity, lively carbonation. Not a ton of pumpkin so this beer may disappoint big pumpkin fans. (ironic I know)

Bottle shared by Sparky.  Thanks E!  Cloudy deep amber color pour with a small foamy head.  Aroma of JP yeast, spice and light pumpkin.  Flavor is light sour and funk, with a hint of pumpkin and spice on the finish.  A uniquely delicious take on pumpkin beer.

In short:  Just as expected.  A funky, tart and acidic amber ale with lots of typical pumpkin beer spices.  For Jolly Pumpkin lovers.
How: Bottle 750ml.  Consumed fresh soon after purchase.  Autumn 2010 batch.  Tasting session with Montreal crew.
The look: Cloudy orange-amber body topped by a very small off-white head
In long: Nose has the typical pumpkin beer spices (cinnamon, nutmeg, etc.) on top of the usual Jolly Pumpkin funk.  Taste is a slice lemon pie and a slice of raisin pie, a lot of above mentioned spices, some wood, lots of funk, very tart with a high level of acidity.  Acidity/tartness level was pretty high even by Jolly Pumpkin standards (Bam Bier-like level of acidity and tartness).  Very lively body and carbonation.  This is far from my favorite Jolly Pumpkin.  The strong spiciness and the strong tart funkiness make a strange couple.  But I love that Jolly pumpkin funk so much that it was still a pretty good beer to me.  An original funky Halloween beer, the worst night of the year to be stumbling in despair on the streets bleeding from many stab wounds.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2012 On tap  at Spuyten Duyvil, NYC. Very interesting. Aroma of apple, with a hint of citrus, and leaves. Taste has a sweet start, and gets sour. Palate is oily, with a medium body. Orange, cloudy, with a thin head.

Bottle from December Santa Cruz tasting. Pours a light bronze color with a large off-white head. Good retention and spackled lace chunks. Acetic aroma with obvious pumpkin pie spice notes. Flavor is much the same; very tart and vinegary notes cut by cocoa and nutmeg sweetness. Theres also a pumpkin flesh note. Pretty interesting.

Rating #900 for me.  Woohoo!  Shared by Dasilky1 at his place.  Hazy ruby-amber with huge dense head.  Tiniest hint of pink in the foamy head.  Nose is beautiful.  Mix of sour, farmhouse bretty saison type of thing, cinnamin and allspice.  Unfortunately, the taste isnt nearly as good as the nose.  Sourness disappears in the mouth.  Big fizzy exploding mouthfeel, but not enough backing it up.  Subtle.

On tap at Capones and bottles from Frank A. Smith. It pours orange and cloudy with a decent creamy head. The aroma is a bit sweet with the wild yeast dominating in that aroma Ive grown to love. There are slight pumpkin, very slight, notes on top of the trademark awesome sour flavor that Jolly Pumpkin does. Maybe the best pumpkin beer Ive ever had, but recognizing that it is completely different than the Pumking, which is also most delicious. Cant wait for Chalsk to try this one.

750 ml. bottle from Johns Marketplace in Portland. Batch 604 (8-17-10). Nice fluffy head. Lovely translucent orange body. This looks pretty good. Smells of lemon, orange, cinnamon, and cacao. Its quite pungent. Cinnamon, and other spices blend well with the sour flavor. Its rather tart at first and then I get a lingering tartness on the tip of my tongue. The tartness doesnt last long. The cinnamon develops quite well throughout the whole thing. Hints of pumpkin come through, but its hard to detect. The cinnamon is the best compliment to this beer and the sour flavor. It isnt crazy good, but it has some good qualities. Im glad this didnt explode everywhere. Cheers, bitches.

750 mL capped bottle, Batch 610, Bottled 8/13/2010.  Thanks to xxNateBallxx for this one!  Hazy orange pour with a fluffy white head.   Aroma is nutmeg, pumpkin and lactobacillus.  Flavor follows suite. Really tart and dry.   This had got to be the best pumpkin beer ive had to date

750ml thanks to MJGG.
Appearance : Hazy orange with a small head.

Aroma : Nice pumpkin, nice tartness. Notes of wheat. Great spices.

Taste : Nice light tartness with a light sourness. Nice pumpkin spices. Rather dry with a nice tart finish. Light fruits and wheat.

Overall : One of the best pumpkin beers Ive had so far (and I dont specially like the style). Very drinkable. Not too sour, nice tartness with nice pumpkin spices. Top notch brew !

A: The pour is a hazy orange color with a short lived, fizzy white head.

S: Like most Jolly Pumpkin beers, some light tartness on the very front end. Quite fruity with some peaches, lemons, grapes, and even citrus zest. Theres a bit of a spice character to this as well as some grass and hay.

T: The taste starts off with damp oak, grass, and hay. The tartness is mild, but there are still some good peach, green apple, and lemon flavors. Not too much in terms of pumpkin, but a bit of sweetness and some all-spice flavor, too.

M: The body is medium with a medium to high level of carbonation.

D: Im sort of a sucker for Jolly Pumpkin beers, so I was pretty sure I would like this. Not sure if its worth the price, but I enjoyed it.

750 mL capped bottle, Batch 610, Bottled 8/13/2010 - sampled 12/10/10: Clear golden amber color with a very persistent ivory cream.  Strong yeasty aroma with the lightest hints of all spice, cinnamon, grains of paradise, and ginger.  Bitter sourdough flavours are striking on the tip of the tongue and mellow quickly...orange zest, flower petals and lemongrass round out a pumpkin beer that is more like a spiced farmhouse ale than many of the sweet/spicy concoctions out there these days...As my wife said: this beer tastes more like the pumpkin patch (funky barnyard flavours) than an actual pumpkin.  Well said babe...

25 oz bottle.  Pours a hazy orangish amber body with a huge frothy off-white head that grew out of my glass.  The nose is a nice mix of pumpkin meat and cinnamon, just a light hint of funkiness fo a JP beer, some light woody notes, and some subtle marshmallow.  The flavor is funky and bretty as hell.  Really great wild flavor without any acid at all, I wish there were more beers like this.  The pumpkin and spicing take a back seat to the funk, but I think it has a really nice squash/earthy base for the funk to play off.  Lingering barrel notes and brett on the finish.  Almost completely dry, with nice lively but soft carbonation.  The mouthfeel really improved from a bit of breathing time allowing it to blow off some of that vigorous carbonation.  Delicious beer all around.  One of the easiest drinking JP beers Ive had.  If Id have known this was so good I would have bought a few!

Nice aroma of fruit, squash, spicy, sour, vinegar, and notes of bread dough.  The appearance is a hazy orange, white head.  The flavor is like the aroma, more fruit, more vinegar, and caramel.  The finish is both peppery and acidic/sour.  Medium in body, slightly thin.  Roughly like a cross between and belgian, a sour and a pumpkin ale.  Very good.

[Tap] Light orange pour with a small cap of off white foam. The aroma is of funk, pumpkin spices and lemongrass. The pumpkin is definitely there in the taste, but more subtle than you might expect. Soured grain, nutmeg, brown sugar and green apple notes are there as well. Its an odd mix of flavors, but actually wasnt too bad. It could have used a little more balance though. High carbonation level and a tad light in body. Not bad.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2010 Bottle from SL. Poured like an orange Orval. Smelled like a pumpkin Orval, some dry yeast, the pumpkin underplayed? Flavor was a bret, light fruits, faint pumpkin (in a good way), about everything youd imagine a JP Pumpkin brew, but I just wasnt digging the combo of bret sour and pumpkin. Go figure. Mouthfeel, fwiw, was like a typical dry JP bretty sour. Not bad.

Bouteille de 750 ml. Arômes dépices à citrouille (cannelle, muscade), de chêne et de levure rustique. Belle touche citronnée. Robe orangée et trouble, légère dentelle et effervescence moyenne. En bouche, les épices sont à lavant-plan, mais bien équilibrées par une belle touche citronnée de levures sauvages (on reconnaît la signature caractéristique de JP). Légères touches de céréales, de cacao et de bois. Finale légèrement acidulée. Une bière goûteuse, mais qui demeure facile à boire.

Bottle courtesy of bulldogb04.  Poured a hazy, warm golden amber with an average sized soapy white head.  Nose is big on JP funk with notes of pumpkin pie spice, light cocoa, and a touch of lemon.  Medium body with a prickly mouth feel.  Flavor is tart with minimal sweetness, up front big malt and spicy yeast notes, midway through it opens up with a zesty lemon note, I get more spice then pumpkin but a definite vegetal quality.  Finishes dry with a lingering brett note.

Aroma: Sour, barnyard, pumpkin pie, allspice.

Appearance: Cloudy copper pour. Dense, tawny head with excellent retention and lacing.

T: Tart, horse blanket, allspice, pumpkin pie (slight). As the brew warmed, the pumpkin pie charcter increased a bit, though not as "pumpkiny" as some others of the style Ive had, such as Southern Tiers Pumking

P: Well carbonated, nicely dry finish, well-balanced.

OA: Im a huge fan of JPs ales, and this one is no exception. Id class it as more of a sour rather than in the vegetable/spice/herb class. The pumpkin is muted and the sour really overshadows it.

Bottle enjoyed on Thanksgiving. Pours an amber orange with a large fluffy white head atop.  Nose is coriander, yeast, sugar, and farmhouse.   Taste is tart... sugary, lemon, citrus, slight yams.   Good fizzy Jolly Pumpkin brew, not overly intense.

Bottle. Batch 610, Bottled 8-20-10. Pours a very hazy sediment infused yellowish orange color with a massive lingering foamy head. Flavor is lactic and slightly tart with hints of pumpkin spice. Light and fizzy on the palate, highly carbonated. Flavor is lingering mildly dry notes of pumpkin and cocoa. Interesting take on the style, but Im not sure that I would know this had pumpkin in it if the bottle didnt say so.

bottle from phaleslu consumed with parents.  pours a lightly hazed copper with a big pillowy white head.   notes of soured bready pudding and spice notes.   pumpkin is not so prominent.  light lactic and acetic acid sourness.  pumpernickel bread.   super easy to drink.    light.  complex.   well made spiced holiday brew.   nice.

Pours a cloudy orange copper with thick frothy head. Aroma is quite tart, almond. Flavor is is tart with notes of hay, grass. Not very much pumpkin flavor or cocoa flavor. Confused by the description and the actual beer.

This stuff was killer! .. As a huge funk fan but not at all a pumpkin fan, this was good vs evil .. . touches of spice with a beautiful air of funk, a nice balance . .. i liked it.. how many times have I told you to pick that damn thing up? A lot, I think. Probably several, ...maybe.

On tap at Crunchys, East Lansing. Murky orange-brown body, medium-thick light buff head. Spicy nose, lactic, with nutmeg. The body is rather dry and acidic, featuring pumpkin spice, oak, and vegetal notes, with a tannic, dry finish. The spicing is not particularly unusual for a pumpkin beer, but the tannic acidity and lactic notes are unique.

Tap at BT.  Pours a hazed deep gold or lightish copper with a thinning head.  Aroma is actually a nice balance of typical JP funky unique brett which has its own spice character of sorts- and then balanced with a modest and not overpowering pumpkin pie spice- cinnamon, clove, allspice, etc.- moderate sweetness and cracker with light dusty cobwebs as well.  Flavor is toasty, good funk, bretty, with light pumpkin spicing, zesty tart twang towards the middle and end, with a slight cherry pie funkiness, and a mostly dry crackery finish.  Not crazy good, but not nearly as bad as I was expecting based on some peoples thoughts on the beer (although they had super fresh).  I think this will continue to evolve and perhaps get even better.

(bottle - corked & caged 750 ml) Rating #2500. Dark brown pour with a thin layer of off-white head. Mild spice and pumpkin notes with a slight touch of that Jolly Pumpkin funk. The pumpkin isnt the overpowering pumpkin pie spice but actual pumpkin flavor with a touch of spice to enhance it. Some lightly sour notes near the end with a mildly sweet and spiced finish.
11/12/10.  Bomber courtesy Tim!  Funky, woody, yeasty sour aroma with a hint of pumpkin spices.  Sour woody tannic flavor with hints of general squash and a dash of spice and chocolate.  Nice!
Draft. Pours brown with an off-white head. Flavor is pumpkin pie with JP funk. Definitely one of the better pumpkin beers Ive tried, the tart notes are interesting.
Sour funk with light citrus, touch of spice, and refreshing fruit notes.  Nutmeg, cinnamon, light cocoa, and tart fruits.  A really nice brew.

Gold, fluffy white head.  Nose is JP funk, lemonhead candy, some light spices & cocoa.  Flavor follows, with light tartness.  The sample I had @ the JP Cafe in Ann Arbor seemed to have some lacto going on but I dont get it in the bottled version.

Bottle, Batch 610 (8/20/10). Cloudy orange with a sustaining white head and bubbly lacing. Nose is quite fragrant with pumpkin and autumn-like spices such as cinnamon, cardamon, and allspice. Flavor is a bit flat, pumpkin and spices up front that quickly fade into a dry and bitter finish. Medium body, prickly carbonation (bottle foamed over), and watery thin texture. Fairly quotidian pumpkin ale, better than most in this oft-saturated style category but well below noteworthy for repeat performances.

Hazy amber pour with a medium porous head. Nice pumpkin, nutmeg and ginger coming through ont he nose with hints of earthyness and barnyard funk. Not too overly sweet on the nose, but very pleasant. Taste is not what I was expecting from the smell. Vinegar, lemon, lots of funk, tangelo and spice. Finishes thin, crisp and slightly astringent.

Orangy tan with an out of control pillowy white head!  Definite  barnyard and sour notes in the aroma.  The front of the taste is an citrusy sweet/sour/bitter followed immediately by a wild yeast funkiness and then again immediately by excellent pumpkin pie spiciness.   I was concerned at first by the apparent "Brett" flavor because Im not a big fan of this, but it is perfectly balanced here with the spices, malt and everything else going on here.  In fact, I wonder if this is the pumpkin coming through and not yeast as it can have this effect.   This is the most interesting pumpkin beer Ive ever had and its a case study in balancing complex flavors without overdoing anything or ending up with a muddled mess.

Bottle: Pours a dark brown color with a nice puffy white head. The nose is spicy with lots of cinnamon, clove and nutmeg with some light oak and yeast notes. The flavor is malty and spicy up front with a light pumpkin pie note then a yeasty slap of tartness in the tail along with a moderate amount of body, not bone dry. Full flavor and a clean spicy finish. I dont know if I love the idea of a savory pumpkin beer with all that oak and tart yeast notes, but it drinks fairly easy.

Bottle from Olive Tree.  Pours a hazy orange amber with a bubbly off white head.  Light oaky funk on the nose as well as light spice, cocoa dust and pumpkin / squash notes.  An insanely drinkable beer.
Meh - sour, flat, and absolutely no pumpkin flavor - NOT a do over for sure!

Bottle. Batch 604. Amber beer with a big cream colored head. Tart and light citrus aroma with light spice. Tart, lemony flavor with spice and malt. Medium bodied. Tart and lemon lingers with spice and light malt. Spice, but not much pumpkin.

11/10/10 notes: on tap, SoCal.  Pour is light brown-amber, clear with a small head.  Aroma is funky/barnyard/earthy first, then spiced/peppery, citrus pith and acidity.  Flavor holds well-integrated tartness to match hay, cereal and general oak barrel influence.  Is pumpkin in there?  Though nothing jumps forward, this is a well-crafted Wild ale.

Murky golden color with a huge pillowy off white head that left big lace.  Funky barnyard aroma with wet wood that seems to overpower a faint spice.  This is not your average pumpkin seasonal.  This is a sour beer with some funk, moldy hay and a hint of cloves.  This seems like a  pretty good funky beer with some spice added as an afterthought.
Clear golden with a fluffy white head. Pumpkin and cacao aroma and taste with a silky palate.

Draft at pizzeria paradiso.  Pours a hazy orange brown.  Spicy flavor with lemony tartness.  Very dry and funky.  Notes of nutmeg and clove.  Maybe a bit overcarbonated but its jolly pumpkin so thats expected.

750mL bottle.  Batch #610.  Bottled on:  08/13/10.  Pours a murky rust color with a thick and fluffy meringue-like head that leaves chunks of lacing down the side of the glass.  Fairly sour aroma that features some caramel maltiness, cinnamon, nutmeg, a little vanilla, and a big lemon presence throughout.  Thin to medium-bodied.  A bit of caramel upfront in the taste.  Drying biscuity flavors follow along with touches of wintry spices.  A bitter finish.  A BIG sour lemon taste throughout.  I dont get it...does Jolly Pumpkin aim to have all their beers taste somewhat infected?

Tap, City Beer Store.  Good beer, but sorta middle of the road for JP.  I didnt really taste any pumpkin.  Some light holiday-ish spices, but this beer sticks to JP sour/oak character much more closely than expected.  Nice and dry taste.  Fairly funky.  Nice looking beer - darkened amber with a big head.
Pours cloudy golden with strong ultra pilllowy head.  Overtones of ginger and citrus.  Flavor is a bit sour with ginger and mild hops.  Nice overall.

75cl bottle.  Large rocky white head atop murky amber body.  Aroma is medium sweet, ginger, some orange, light clove, cocoa.  Taste is moderately sweet, orange, some ginger, light sour.  Light-medium body, light creaminess.

Pours a deep tan with LOTS of quickly rising off-white head.  Nose is barnyard funk and lots of belgian yeast.  Flavor is a bit of hops, some sourt Jolly Pumpkin twang, but mostly this beer is just classic farmhouse ale.  I dont get it.  It isnt a pumpkin ale at all.  I liked it, probably more than my rating would imply.  But Im giving it a lower "overall" score than I might otherwise because it isnt what it claims to be.  I was really looking forward to my first pumpkin ale of the season, but I guess Ill have to wait a bit longer!

750ml bottle from bev4less. Batch 610.  Pours a cloudy copper color with a huge clumpy white head that has good retention and crazy lacing. The aroma is strong and overtly funky with sour pumpkin, oak, vanilla, cloves and brett. The taste profile is similar to the nose, loads of sour pumpkin, mild spices, biscuit, lemons and persimmons. The palate was smooth with prickly carbonation. Finishes long and sour. Overall: Very nice sour pumpkin ale.

Draft from The Good Pie.  Pours a clear, bright amber color with a finger-thick off-white head.  Some lace.  Aroma of sour grapes, tart apples, fall spices, funk, and a little bit of a vegetal/earthy note that must be the pumpkin.  Flavor is also sour, tart, and fruity, with spices, sweet and toasted malts, funk, and more pumpkin than the nose.  Light-bodied, with subtle but crisp carbonation and an apple juice mouthfeel.  Funky finish.  The pumpkin here is very subdued and gives way to a very cool spicy, sour beer.  I didnt quite know what to expect but enjoyed this a lot.

Bottle.  Poured a hazy orangish copper with a small tan head.  Nose of sweet tart fruit, with smoe spice.  Taste is mix of fruit, light pumpkin, spice and sweet malts.  A bit of tart fruit in there as well, though not as funky as most other JP brews.  Overall, a decent and interesting pumpkin ale, thats not overlly funky or pumpkiny.

Batch 610. Bottled 8/13/10.

The beer pours a yellow-orange-amber color with a white head. The aroma begins as your basic pumpkin ale. I get some nutmeg, cinnamon and pumpkin. However, since it is a Jolly Pumpkin beer, you know there will be some tartness and it is present in the aroma. 

The flavor is pumpkin, brett, nutmeg and cinnamon. There is also a low amount of tartness in the flavor, but the beer is more funky than sour.

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. 

A very nice, interesting take on a pumpkin beer. Glad I got to try this one.

Bottle and draft from Capones. Pours an opaque light brownish orange with a thick, bubbly, frothy white head. Aroma of nutmeg, ginger bread, tart, sourdough bread, and subtle notes of fresh pumpkin and dry hops. Medium bodied with a rich, tonge-coatingly tart palate. Slight sourness through the finish with notes of pumpkin rising before the final flourish. Very cool Pumpkin ale from the Jolliest of Pumpkins. Happy Halloween!

Bottle (batch 604)...  Poured hazy, dark, burnt orange with a thick, fizzy, white head with nice retention.  Some Brett on the nose, funky and musty with yeast and spices.  Drinking, it tasted tart with a mild pucker, the funish showcased the pumpkin-squash notes with hints of cloves, nutmeg.  Clean yeast flavors, and even a mild hoppiness in this brew.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2010 Hazy pour with a big head. Tart aroma with various fruit. Tart flavor as well various fruit and spice.  The flavor is nothing like any pumpkin beer Ive had before, but very typical to Jolly Pumpkin.  Again, tart fruit flavors with a touch of spice, a bit of nuttyness and earth.  Nothing really pumpkin about it but it is quite tasty.  Medium body and refreshing for a fall beer.

Im a big pumpkin beer fan and I was pretty excited to try this beer. Ive known for quite some time that Jolly Pumpkin is known for their sour/wild ales, so I expected this to be somewhat on the sour side, but maybe with a kick of pumpkin. Well it was more sour kick then pumpkin, thats for sure. I wish there could have been a bigger pumpkin presence, but every pumpkin beer cant be a home run.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2011 Tap @ Choice City. Cloudy brown orange appearance with an off white head. Spicy, olive-like, tangy citrusy, orange fruity aroma. Tart, orange fruity, citrusy, somewhat spicy, floral, earthy flavor. Pretty nice brew.

aroma- yeast, candied sugar, cinnamon, brown sugar, pumpkin.  pours amber/gold/orange.  taste is pumpkin, wild yeast, citrus lemon, oak, very light pumpkin on finish with some spicy notes.  palate was medium bodied.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2010 Draught at KC F.S. Very interesting take on the fall pumpkin ale. This was a straight up funky sour ale at first and then finished with some pumpkin and spice. Very light mouthfeel and refreshing. As nice as Pumking but in a totally different way.

On tap at Maxs in Baltimore. Pours copper orange with a thin white head. Aroma is funk, maybe a hint d pumpkin but not much. Leather, bandage good funk kick. Flavor is sour, tart a bit spicy. Really excellent beer.

750s from Capones and Smittys.  Pours turbiud orangy jack-o-lantern colored (big surprise there, DUH).  with frothy off white head that lingers longer than the ghost of your mother-in-law.  Nose is funky, yeasty, nit much pumpkin but a lot of fruit and malt.  Tastes tart, funky, fruity, floral, with backup hops and more pumpkin puree as it warms.  Never gets sweet, stays complex throughout, and is very enjoyable.  This one is much more complex than your run of the mill pumpkin beers, but not perhaps as enjoyable as something like ST Pumking.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2013 Bottle split with and courtesy of pat. Pours a thick hazy amber body with nice carbonated head. Aroma is typical JP sour. Mouthfeel is tart and well carbonated with notes of sour and tart dominating - very slight pumpkin spice in the background. Great sour, not sure if I could group this with any other pumpkin brew.

bottle had yeast gunk on inside of neck, odd, like it was stored upside down? wiped it off, but i dunno.
aroma is yeasty and sour backed by pumpkin spices -- interesting mix, but not my favorite. sour pumpkin pie? 
flavor is mild, tart, fairly dry, with some sweet vegetables.
pours hazy orange-amber with wispy white head.
body is slightly on the thin side of medium, also a bit flat, with a small tart finish.

Bottle: Pours a hazy orange with a consistent white head. Complex funky aroma- cherry pit, mild citric notes, soft oak, perhaps a subtle touch of nutmeg. Thin body with a light flavor. Mildly tart- a citric note and quite tannic. The oaky tannins clash with what mild spices are there with a touch of later astringency. Close to being great, but somehow the tannins of the barrel and the spices clash.
750ml bottle shared by jsprime. amber pour with a lasting off white head. funky JP nose. flavour starts with acid upfront, then some pumpkin flesh, spices at the finish. very nice seasonal from JP.

750mL bottle purchased at the Davis Food CO-Op.  Batch 611 bottled on 08/18/10.  Aroma is funky, but somewhat smooth with some vanilla notes and a little floral/perfume, too.  Light cereal.  Moderately hazy golden-orange body with a fizzy whitish head.  Starts a little tart and acidic.  Has some vegetal notes in the middle with some chewiness.  Finishes with flavors that resemble cool McDonalds french fries.  This is decent, but not overly enjoyable or worth the $16 price tag.
Amber in color with a small head, hint of spice with very little pumpkin taste, aroma is excellent, and the sour first taste to the sweet finish is intersting.

Not the best pumpkin beer but the most unique, first sour punk beer I have had.Aroma is great pumpkin,spice and sweet tarts.Pours cloudy amber with a off white head.Starts tart then sweet and ends sour.Over all great beer .

pours a hazy orange, with a med to small head.  Aroma of sweet tarts, and spice. Taste has pumpkin notes but can not taste and spice. This is a very unqiue beer even if your not a big pumpkin beer drinker.

i like the label... the aroma is very pumpkin note-able  one of the best smells of a pumpkin beer. the appearance is reminiscent of a pumpkin pie. the taste change fast but good. it was a little bitter, but yet again the flavor changes quick and for the good to a sweet and sour i makes this beer unique. the palate dissipates quick but doesnt leave a bad taste overall i think the palate should of bin a bit longer and thinker for this type of beer never the less still great if you have a chance i rec picking up a bottle just to try even if you normally dont enjoy this style beer. i think you will be surprised

750 ml btl Batch 598 bottled 8-11-10. Pours a hazy apricot hue with a foamy white head. Aroma is a refreshing tangy pumpkin spices and some grapefruit subtlties. Crisp tart lasting sour almost like a green apple cider. Not quites as much pumpkin as Id prefer But a nice spicy autumn quality that sticks around.A great sour seasonal.

Pours a translucent copper with small head. Aroma of tartness and apricot (perhaps just the sour front giving off a fruity appeal).  Some spice and little to no pumpkin. Flavor of a sour, with mostly wood and tartness coming out.  Not sure how to rate a beer I like, altho it doesnt give off much of anything that typically a pumpkin ale offers...including the pumpkin.

Bottle shared by robert at SL. Pours a hazy orange, decent head. Nose of some light spice, cinnamon and pumpkin with an overall tartness. Taste: The tartness/sourness and pumpking really off set each other and didnt blend well. Sour and pumpkin, thats all I tasted. Medium body with lots of carbonation. Overall: A good idea, but just not to my liking at all.

750ml bottle.  batch 610.  bottled 8-13-10.  hazy orange with a small white head.  nose has light touches of pumpkin and spice with some familiar JP funkiness.  flavor has floral notes, da funk, very light pumpkin and spice mostly in the form of cinnamon.  not much pumpkin here is thats what your expecting, but it has a delicate subtleness.  love the artwork.

Pours deep orange into a snifter. White head with medium retention recedes to skim surface. Licorice, nutmeg and pumpkin aromas. Spritzy with upfront caramel, pumpkin, and funk.  Lasting spice finish...

750ml bottle from K&L.  Finally a pumpkin beer from Jolly Pumpkin.  I just love the way this beer looks.  The color is a clear bright pumpkin orange, and the head totally overwhelms the glass with thick white billowing foam.  Thick lacing remains after the clouds recede.  Nice subtle pumpkin aroma.  Jolly Pumpkin usually goes big on the funk, but this time it is restrained.  Spicy with a hint of chocolate.  The flavor also has big pumpkin, a little sweet and only mildly funky, although the house yeast is evident.  Slight cocoa and pie spices balance it out.  Very smooth and silky on the mouthfeel with soft carbonation.  For a pumpkin ale, I think this is great, and Im a big fan of pumpkin beers.  Guess these guys finally lived up to their name and I didnt have to keep calling them Jolly Blump- ok, lets not go there.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2011 Hazy orange-amber with good, creamy, off-white head / Tart nose of orchard fruit, caramel, pumpkin and brett / Light body, acidic and moderately tart, lively, fine, carbonation, with good balance and finish / Flavors of apple, pumpkin, caramel, chrysanthemum, straw, coriander, clove, nutmeg, cocoa, and barnyard funk / Superb, but what isnt from JP.

Pours hazy amber with an off-white head.  The aroma has lots of spice, some funk, some sourness, citrus, bugs and I really concentrate I can maybe / possibly detect a hint of pumpkin.  Medium / light body that is very crisp and has subdued sharp carbonation.  The taste starts with fruit, citrus, bugs and spice.  There is a nice lightly toasted malt and it seems to have a hint of pumpkin.  It seems like the pumpkin is smoothing out some of the JP funk more than giving it flavor.  the finish is spicy and buggy just like Id expect from these guys.  Nice beer & probably my fave pumpkin beer since you can barely tell its there.

Whole foods. Tap. Almost bright amber. Nice blend of funk, tartness and spice on the nose. Dry, tart, spicy, a touch of lemon and cranberry. Light and effervescent. Nice pumpkin beer because it doesnt taste like one.
Draught at Sycamore. Slight pumpkin taste furthered by a distinct wine body. Lots of tang and sour and apple in there as well. Very nice. Didnt pick up much of Alans nibs. Thanks, Sanford!
On tap.  Pours an orangish brown.  Nice pumpkin and spice aroma and tastes with a perfect sour taste.  Best pumpkin beer I had this year hands down.

Nice and complex aroma. Notes of pumpkin and spices...you can almost smell the sourness. Pours a dark reddish orange with a thick white head. Flavor is pumpkin and spices a faint sourness with some pumpkin sweetness
Draft.  Orange pour.  Pumpkin, sweet malt, sourness, nutmeg, and clove.  Interesting pumpkin beer as it is slightly soured.
Poured a pale fizzy brown, nose was spicy, holiday spices in the background, taste is very dry, a nice level of sourness, good funky finish.

Ok, so the joke should be that this isnt really a pumpkin beer. The tartness totally rules here. That being said, this light orange-amber brew has light fizzy carbonation and a very distinct dry tart mouthfeel. Perhaps a little spice, but not really. Drinkable, but dont call this a pumpkin beer. Just another crazy sour from JP.

Bottle. Pours a bright orange color with a white head. Body changes to a more brownish color as it settles. Nose is Belgian yeast with light funk. Palate is playful and fun, crisp, clean. Flavor of light sour Belgian yeast and funk, some light sugar notes. No pumpkin detected, but a very nice beer.

Backlog notes. I didnt feel like rating when this one came along, so my notes are sparse, but heres what they said: Bottle. 2009 436/37. Awesome! Dry. Perfect attenuation. No cocoa. Hint of pumpkin on the finish. Carbonation pitch perfect. Dry as a bone. Spritzy mouthfeel. Earthy and slightly funky. Trademark JP malt profile. Wd. like to try fresh but this works just fine! Thanks Kevin!

Sour and funky aroma. I like it! Pours a rich amber color with modest head that dissipates quickly. Sour tasting with the Jolly Pumpkin house funk. Not a lot of pumpkin flavor at first, just a nice tart/sour malty flavor. After the initial sourness goes away, a very nice pumpkin and chocolate aftertaste remain. Once you know what to look for, the pumpkin has a fresh from the garden character. This beer is not the typical pumpkin pie spice beer we get this time of year, but is a very subtle and complex beer that gives you something new to discover the more you look for new things to discover. Its odd, I love this beer and it is more complex than other pumpkin beers, but in a pumpkin beer competition it would not do well because the pumpkin is not in your face.

Year old 750ml bottle courtesy of tytoanderso. Pours a BEAUTIFUL golden orange with a small white head with a small amount of sediment floating around.  Big aroma consisting of pumpkin, sour yeast, spices (nutmeg, cloves, coriander), with an almost mentholated funk.  Largely tart flavor, minerals, grassy upfront with the pumpkin flavors subtlety lingering behind a large layer of funk.  Acidic as hell.  Awesome.  High level of carbonation usher in spices and funk that roll into an acidic finish.  never thought I would like a pumpkin beer so much.  Fantastic! Thank you tytoanderso for sharing this wonderful beer!!!

This poured a cloudy bright orange color with a normal sized off white head. Aroma was of light spices, nutmeg and cinnamon, as well as dusty funky straw and brett. Flavor was a bit confusing, fairly tart and funky but with the spices of a pumkin beer. Not really exactly what Im looking for in a pumpkin beer, but a decent one overall at that.

Thanks to tytoanderso... again.  From a bottle, the pour is  orange with a small white head.  Aroma is of pumpkin spice with a slight funkiness.  It is hard to discern but im guessing there is something like clove, nutmeg, and/or cinnamon.  Taste is slight funk, spice, and tart!  The spice is nutmeg, and clove.  Maybe cinnamon.  Dry finish.  If you have this, drink it.

Bottle: &nbsp Dark dirty straw, moderate white head spritzy head, dies quickly, spotty lacing. &nbsp Subtle notes of cinnamon and nutmeg, but a larger barnish aroma. &nbsp Also floral. &nbsp Seems like a Saison with some Pumpkin like spices. &nbsp Very barnish and floral up front. &nbsp Any pumpkin like spices take a back seat. &nbsp  Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Mildly tart, slightly dry on the finish. &nbsp This is a funky Pumpkin Ale, more in common with a Saison in its funky barnish floralness. &nbsp Wished the Pumpkin spices were stronger. &nbsp Thanks Kevin for this rarity!

Bottle @ Buckeye Beer Engine: arouma is tart and cinnamon spice and caramel malts. Well balanced by lactic acids, pumpkin and lighter fruit. nice dry finish. Wish more brewers would make funky, sour pumpkin beers because this just hit the spot.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2010 Bottle at Beer Engine.  Rerate.  Hazy amber pour.  The aroma is incredible.  Softly sweet with a lot of pumpkin spice and a soft leathery undertone as well.  Soft funkiness with the spice backing that up.  A kiss of mintiness behind the spice and the brett.  Softly fruity finish with a touch of soft tartness.  Lean body despite the soft sweet flavour.  Lingering minerally/minty finish.  Really awesome stuff.

Deep golden-amber pour.  The nose has a lot of soft sourness and vineous tartness.  Softly lactic character and a fairly wild flavour.  A little bit of light oakiness as well as some wheaty spiciness.  The smell is great but something about the flavour just doesnt sit right with me.  Warming brings up a kiss of other spices as well.  I want to like this, but I dont really.
8 3 6 3 13

750 ml bottle. This one pours a hazy, dark orange color and topped by a small, bubbly off white head that settles quickly to a thin film. The aroma shows that classic JP funk with notes of earthy spices and oak along with notes of pumpkin, tart fruits, and a cereal grain malt base. Cinnamon, clove, and cocoa also add to the spice mix. The flavor follows and is slightly tart from citrus fruits to go with the cereal grain and pumpkin flesh. Notes of cinnamon, clove, and cocoa come through as well. The brett is slightly dry and adds a touch of funk and some earthy characters. Medium bodied and crisp on the palate with plenty of carbonation and a dry finish. This is an interesting take on the pumpkin beer style.

Bottle at Buckeye on our way to RBSG.  Pours a hazed orange gold with a soft beige head.  Soft fuzzy light sour and caramel.  Very faint pumpkin flesh.  Medium bodied, lightly sour.  Long slow gentle sweetness and a little funk.
Poured hazy light reddish brown, citrus, bready, little earthy, little funky, slight spice.
Pours attractive clear ruddy brown. Wonderful nose of pumpkin, tart citrus, and a touch of chocolate. Better flavor with same influence. Lovely yet smooth on the palate.

Bottled. Has that signature Jolly Pumpkin sourness, but it is relatively light. Some cucumber and nail polish remover. The pumpkin is there, but its mellow. Good mouthfeel, but there is a harsh solventy character all throughout this. Something seems to have gone here.

Bottle shared by SpencerDB on 6/6/10: Pours a cloudy deep bronze copper with a stringy-lacing white head.  Has a semi-sweet floral pumpkin character and a hint of tartness and mild funk.  Starts with decent body and effervescent carbonation with some light biscuity malty sweetness and some fleshy pumpkin flavor.  Finishes with a light tartness and some grassy hay with good bitter balance.  An enjoyable and complex pumpkin ale.

bottle via sparky on 3/21/10.

hazy pale pumpkin pie tinted brown colored pour with a thin off white head.

it smells like pumpkin earthiness, caramel, cinnamon, slate, citrus/orange, faint skunky hops and a little mustiness.... all with the usual jp funk in the background.

the flavor is similar... i dont get as much of the pumpkin sweetness and a lot more citrus comes through. this time it is lemon peel... all with the usual jp funk. 

the crisp medium body is zesty and refreshingly dry.8/4/8/4/16/4.0

Sampled at DC Epic Sour Tasting 2010.  Pours a translucent, nearly transparent, orange with a sticky white head.  Nose is vegetal, sweet, spices, yeast.  Flavor is sweet, spicy, malty, yeasty, oranges, apple juice.  Finish is medium bodied and lightly sweet.

750 ml bottle at DC Epic Sour Tasting 2010, courtesy of Spencer, thanks!  Cloudy yellow, white head.  Aroma of pumpkin and light spice.  Finally a pumpkin beer that doesnt taste of pumpkin pie and overwhelming nutmeg!

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2012 750mL courtesy of SpencerDB. Pours a clear yellow with a thin, white head that leaves little lace. Aroma is pumpkin spices, pumpkin pie, all very light and soft. Taste is a bit tart, has some light pumpkin spice, and overall is light bodied with spritzy carbonation. Decent.  750mL 2012 ed thanks to dfroms. Full haze orange with a weaker white head. Nose is squashy, pumpkin, spice. Taste is cinnamon, big lemon lime, a tad thin. Refreshing, citric.
Sweet pumpkin spice nose, light honey, some caramel. The taste is lightly sweet, lightly tart, spicy, some cinnamon, touch of squash, some fruit. Reminds me of a lighter version of Noel.

Thanks to Orlando crew for the sample. Pours a hazy golden color. Nose is funky and sour as expected from JP as well as some citrus notes. Flavor is the same as the nose with a touch of pumpkin flavor and lemon as well. Nice beer especially being a pumpkin beer.

A little sweet, a little sour, not much in the way of pumpkin flavor, unless my palate was dead (could be!). But thats good, because I dont normally like pumpkin beers and this is the first one I really liked! Nice.

750ml courtesy of Fiver 29 and shared at Hellbillys Shootout in Sosco Tasting.  Pours a hazy amber with a thin off-white head.  The nose is light spice, the usual JP funk and citrus zest.  The taste is funk, light pumpkin spice and lemon peel.  Medium prickly mouthfeel.  Refreshing stuff, though Id prefer a touch more pumpkin and less funk.  Thanks for sending J!

Smells like pumpkin, nutmeg, other spice, and some citrus.  Looks very pretty - orangey red with a little bit of lingering head.  The taste is a little sour for me - lemon and wood tasting, with very little pumpkin flavor.  Good carbonation to it.

750mL bottle, Batch 436/437.  Poured clear medium golden with a short, tight-bubbled whitish head.  The aroma picked up sour nutmeg and oaky notes with a little lemon zest too.. just the faintest hints of pumpkin and cocoa deep down.. smelled like it was going to be refreshing.  The flavor found refreshing sourness all the way through (mostly lemon rind and oak).. dry nutmeg and pumpkin-y spices rose toward the back of the mouth, as did the lemon.. very dry and tangy on the finish.  Medium-bodied with tight, sharp carbonation complementing the lemon and oak.. surprisingly light on the pumpkin and related spices.. refreshing as mentioned.. definitely a Jolly Pumpkin take on a pumpkin ale.

sampled from bottle.  faint haze of suspended yeast gives it a dull but glowing bronze/orange color with a small off-white head.  initial impression of the nose is of how delicate and soft the spices are layered on top of whats already a very delicate and soft yeast: the "with spices" is most definitely pumpkin spice (with nutmeg being most pronounced and cinnamon perhaps present in very small quantity).  texture is spot-on for JP: intensely delicate natural carbonation with a soft chewiness from the yeast.  extremely well-attenuated, the malt sugar seems nearly completely fermented out (which makes me curious how strict JP are about the use of speciality malts, or if they are simply just masters of mash and temperature rests - perhaps the most skillful at this process of anyone outside of europe). very low apparent unfermentable sugar present. cocoa is pretty much unnoticeable, while the oak barrel wood character (which overall is fairly light) and the subtle acidity (much closer to wine acidity than beer; i.e. not sour) from the inoculated barrel are fantastically balanced and in harmony with the other two major arms of this beer: the pumpkin spice and high attenuation.  damn fine stuff.

Like a lot of JP beers, this one took a moment to grown on me - at first, I thought it simply tasted like an infected pumpkin ale, which I guess, in essence, it is, but a might good one - nose of oak, thankgiving potpourri, a wee bit of funk, and a bit of waxiness - present but restrained amounts of acidity and funkiness, especially for JP - an overall nice balance - the spices (cinnamon, nutmeg) add an interesting dimension - I hope this gets wider distribution this year.

Courtesy of gunhaver. Pours hazy copper with gold edges and white head. The aroma has loads of tartness with a sense of pumpkin around the edges. The taste is the same with a boat load of tartness up front with notes of sour citrus thinly lined around the periphery. It ends with a bit of refreshing dryness. Pumpkin Ale?

Thanks gunhaver for the share.  Pours hazy orange with an off-white head.  Nose is pumpkin, spice, cinnamon, yeast, vinegar, and the trademark JP funk.  Flavor is the trademark JP funk, vinegar, yeast, some pumpkin, some acetone, and tart fruit.  Finish lingers with tart fruit, vinegar, and a hint of spice in this medium-bodied beer.

courtesy of gunhaver.
pours cloudy orange, thin white head.
Aroma of light pumpkin with the signature yeasty JP aroma, oaky wood, yeasty elements white grapes/wine.
Flavors, very weak pumpkin presence mixed with Belgian yeast, oaky, barrel, white wine palate along with other tropical fruits and orange leaving a nice sour finish.
I was expecting a lot more pumpkin in this one, instead I got the immediate JP feel that resembles all the other beers. Tasty, but just wanted something different.

Bottle shared by Sparky27 @ Hellbillys.  Thanks Eric.  Murky golden tangerine pour with ivory head.  Standard JP funk with tart lemon peel, wood, and slight pumpkin spice.   Wanted more pumpkin in this one.  Enjoyable but not as expected.

750 ml bottle shared by Sparky27 - Pours a hazy golden color with a small off white head.  Aroma and flavor is tart esters and spice.  Very little pumpkin.  A typical JP beer.  Tartness lingers a bit.  Medium body.  To be honest, I was a little disappointed with this one.  Thanks Eric.
Thanks to sparky27.  Orange pour.  Light pumpkin, lots of funk and tartness.  Wood and lactic tartness.  Not bad...pretty good actually.
courtesy of s27 pours a orange with a white head aroma is hops pumpkin and malt. flavor is pimpkin malt hops a touch of sournesss. thanks eric

Bottle.  Pour is dirty copper/ orange with a thin ring of white foam.  Aroma is tart, light malt, and a very light pumpkin spice character.  Flavor is quite tart- did not see that coming but I really liked it.  Also notes of funk and lightly roasty finish with a lightly herbal finish.

750ml bottle by way of beastiefan2k.  Funky, spicy aroma, lightly fruity and tart, perhaps a hint of the pumpkin, farmy and very lightly citric, also some faint wood.  Cloudy medium orange color, head is fine and lasting.  Flavor is similarly funky, spicy, tart and very lightly sweet, seeing some mild hop bitterness and fruit creep in towards the finish, drying out somewhat and really chock full of yeast character from beginning to end.  Nicely balanced and some decent complexity, mouthfeel is smoothly effervescent and lightly acidic with a medium body.  Pretty nice.

750 ml bottle shared by beastiefan2k. Thanks. Poured a hazy gold with a thin white head. Fairly sour aroma with just a hint of pumpkin pie spice. Nice tart flavor. Very refreshing. Lighter bodied. Some dark sugar in the middle. Tart cherry in the finish. I didnt get a whole lot of pumpkin, but enjoyable none the less.

750 ml bottle shared by beastiefan2k.  Batch 436/437 marked on the sticker on the back of the bottle. Pour is a hazed orange golden with a smallish white head. Aroma of sourish sweet, nutmeg, some of generic cooking vegetable.  Overall the nose is interesting and bright. Taste is the vegetable of the nose (showing more pumpkin in the taste), then really quickly moves to sour and lactic, along with the yeast clove and nutmeg. Quite a bit going on, but soft and nicely integrated. Really unique taste. Palate is highly carbonated with a medium to thin body. Nice one, thanks for sharing Eugene, I had really wanted to try this one.

750ml, batch 436/437, thanks for sharing Eugene.  Pours a hazy golden with a minimal white head.  Aroma is fresh pumpkin and nice complimentary spice, with a hint of chocolate and some dank must.  Flavor leads with more brief pumpkin, spice and finishes with some sour notes.  A little too much carbonation but nice overall.  Classically JP if that makes sense...

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2011 Enjoyed the beer tonight on draft at Coffee Disrict in Delray Beach.  


Bottle (Batch 436/437) Cloudy golden ale with a small, creamy, white head.  The aroma is earthy and woody with an acidic back bone, but I get no pumpkin. Smells nice nonetheless. Light to medium-bodied with an astringent mouthfeel and lively carbonation. The flavor is fairly sour and I do pick up just a touch of pumpkin. Finishes tart, coarse and bone-dry. Bottle co
urtesy of cmillward!
Shared by bhensonb. Pours clear golden with a fluffy white head and a fruity aroma. Yes, this is a pumpkin beer, with some allspice and lots of vegetable. On of the better pumpkin ales I have had.

750 from Guerde, Styles or ericandersnavy. Had it for awhile. Apologies for the bad memory. Pours light amber with a foamy three=-finger head. Smells of pie spice and funk. Medium body with mild carbonation. Lightly sour, towards medium funky. Excellent.

Got to try a bottle of this thanks to, "hannont".  Colour... golden-orange with no head. Nose... Whoa! Get a whiff of Dr. Funkandspice!! With some polystyrene thrown in as well! Palate... bright, lively acidity on the tongue, spicy notes, tangy on the soft palate, a general funkiness with a medium oak, dryish finish.

(750ml, Batch 436/437, courtesy of blutt59)  Pours a cloudy orange body with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of lemon, horse blanket, pumpkin, and nutmeg.  Flavor of yeast, black pepper, pumpkin, peach, and citrus.

750ml bottle, batch 436/437 blend, courtesy cmillward.  Pours a hazy, glowing, medium orange-amber hue.  A small, frothy, ivory colored head settles in to a thin patch with a bubbly edge.  Tiny spots of lacing are strewn about the glass.  Aromas kick off with the signature JP funk, prominently showing oaky, earthy brett over a base of softly sweet cereal grain, fresh pumpkin, and general fruity tartness.  Dusty cinnamon, clove, and cocoa lend subtle, complimentary spice.  Flavors are tart, but not overly so, showing a hint of lemon that is quickly neutralized by the grain and sweet pumpkin.  Everything gets a soft dose of the cocoa and clove, and cinnamon makes an appearance as well.  Brett remains softly funky and dry, imparting a grounding earthiness.  On the palate, a medium-light, crisp body offers fine, active carbonation and a drying, thirst quenching finish.  Chalk up another interesting, enjoyable concoction from Jolly Pumpkin.

750 ml bottle from HPWS.  Pours a slightly hazy golden amber color with a large foamy off white head that slowly collapses to a thin blanket of creamy bubbles.  The aroma reminds me more off a spiced cider with apples, cinnamon, cherries, and citrus.  The brett and tartness are also there with the usual JP funkiness.  Everything works well together.  The flavor has many similarities with the nose.  The tart citrus and brett show themselves quickly before this reverts back to the spiced cider that came though in the nose.  This is at times sour, while at others the cinnamon and other flavors seem to dominate.  The JP funk is present, but the whole pumpkin thing seems to be missing.  There are some bready malt notes and toasted sensations that come through late.  Medium bodied and very drinkable.  

Rating #61for this beer.

( 750ml bottle thanks to mar bottle #436/437) Pours opaque orange with yeast floaters and nice bubbles. Nose of oak and sour fruit. Taste of nutmeg, lactic acid and good carbonation. This is sour, but not in a good way. Dont think pumpkins make a good sour beer.

Bottle shared with masonjar! Pours a near clear glowing viscous auburn.  Great JP bretty aroma, medium sweet.  Love the pumpkin taste! all the JP goodness with almost fantome like intriguing depth.  A great JP beer!

Thanks turdferguson for sharing. Pours a bright hazy orange with an offwhite head. Nose is spicy and tart, peppery, pumpkin meat, yeasty. Flavor is characteristic JP, nice yeasty tartness intermingling with nutmeg and allspice with a meaty pumpkin background. Tart and peppery on the palate.
Thanks to CMillward for the pour. Orange gold pour. Sour pumpkin, cinnamon aroma. Taste is light and dry, pumpkin and some spices. Finishes nice and dry. Very good.

Thanks to TURDFERGUSON for sharing this one. Dusky brown pour, like an oud bruin, but a lovely tart aroma of mild sour and ripe autumnal fruits, including of course pumpkin. Something very pungent and earthy at work here, as far as possible from the sticky artifical flavors you usually get with this style. Very faint bready and sweets are there if you strain, but its altogether more modest and tart than anything else, with pumpkin being almost like an infusion. Very good.

Bottle, Batch 436/437, 

poured a burnt orange with gold and darker orange hues into a tulip, this brew is a little hazy, produced a slightly off-white head and left decent lacing on the glass, 

this ale has a nose of Pumpkin and vegetable with cinnamon and nutmeg spices, lemon fruit citrus with the JP Sourness, light pale malt, caramel, and some fresh green herbs in the background, 

there are flavors of spice and fruit citrus up front with Pumpkin in the background, JP sourness, and ends with a tart and dry finish, this beer is light on the palate, I thought the flavors melded well, 

when all was done, I found a layer of brown sediment in the bottle, 
probably one of the better Spice-Herb-Vegetable beers I have tried in a while where I am usually hesitant to try Spice-Herb-Vegetable beers, I would buy this again.

Bottle shared by TURDFERGUSON. Thanks, Sam.  Nice label, and I love the description.  Wish I liked the beer a bit more.  But perhaps Im being harsh.  Its certainly one of the better pumpkin beers out there... but is that saying all that much?  Smells like pumpkin pie, crust, fruit, spice and all.  Only a touch of that JP sourness, and maybe a hint more on the palate.  Solid, and with a nice mouthfeel.  Pretty damn good.

Bottle from ogglethorp.  Thanks Brian!   A vey nice, unique pumpkin ale. 
Nice jp house character with a very nice, unique, nuanced pumpkin brew.  I enjoyed this quite a bit.

thanks to cmillward for sharing this one!  Tart and spicy aroma with hints of cinnamon.  Pours a golden orange with a thin white head.  Tart upfront with hints of light caramel followed by hints of spices with a dry pumpkin finish.  Very nice.

Batch 436 / 437; Sampled December 2009
A solid pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces a fat, two finger thick, pale amber, lightly tan colored head that leaves some lacing as it slowly subsides.  The beer is a combination of rich copper and amber hues that shows a lightly hazed, gold-copper hue when held up to the light.  The aroma smells of spicy nutmeg, sweetly vegetal pumpkin meat, a touch of spicy ginger, some white pepper, hints of cinnamon, brown sugar, light toasted grain notes.  Really though this beer smells of a light spiciness and caramelized pumpkin flesh; it is pretty nice and I like the light hand with the actual spices, plus I think the fermentation provided some of the spice notes too.

Surprisingly dry tasting, considering the nose, and there is a nicely soft tartness that says this wasnt fermented in a "clean" Sachoromyces only brewery.  The spiciness comes through in a much more peppery, ginger kind of way in the flavor due to the lack of sweetness.  There is still a touch of pumpkin flesh flavor in the finish, but it is much more subtle.  The beer has a nice texture to it; the fair amount of carbonation couples with the light tartness to bring a peppery sharpness to this as it rolls across the tongue; this is definitely a lighter feeling brew, but it easily keeps from seeming thin.  In fact there seems to be a touch of malt viscosity without any accompanying sweetness.  The peppery note couples with a soft woodiness.

My second pour of this that is drunk quite soon after the pour, is a bit too fizzy and carbonated; luckily a quick swirl of the glass releases the extra carbonation.  The tartness is definitely lactic in nature, which pairs well with the rest of the beer.  Perhaps a touch of lighlty smoky phenolics are noticeable as the beer warms up, but this can be exceedingly fleeting.

This is an exceedingly fantastic Pumpkin beer, definitely one of the best commercial examples that I have ever had.  I like how appetizing and "sweet" the aroma smells, but that the flavor is dry, tart and not anywhere near over-spiced.  The aroma actually reminds me of desert (perhaps obviously), but the flavor is, in the end, quite savory.  I am definitely quite pleased to be drinking a bottle of this right now.

750mL bottle, batch 436/437. Pours a slightly hazy, effervescent, and bold golden-copper color; creamy off-white head with excellent retention and fine-bubbled lacing; a gorgeous pour. The aroma on this is gorgeous and essentially smells like a vibrant mulled apple cider: cinnamon, apples, and some solid citrus acidity (the brett and tartness is there, but it blends rather seamlessly with the apple cider character). Medium mouthfeel: lots of citrus acidity and tartness here: brett and aceto, almost definitely, with a nicely complex melange of contributing sourness; this isnt ultimately what Id consider a sour ale, and the mulled apple cider notes follow through from the aroma, along with plenty of cinnamon and toasty vanilla; light wood and funkiness; the core, honestly, is a bit hollow overall, and feels not entirely filled out; quite drinkable, nice funk, and a very solid contributing presence from the apple cider spicing. Lasting tart finish of citrus, toasty malts, and hints of lingering cinnamon.

Bottle batch 436/437.  Slightly orangish-gold pour with a small white head.  The aroma is freshly baked pumpkin, classic JP funk, and rounded out with a hint of lemon and spice.  The flavor is initially tart and funky upfront with  light pumpkin and nutmeg on the finish.  Theres some notes of light citrus and a slight earthiness from the cacao.  The body is creamy, medium-full with lots of carbonation.

Bottle thanks to Blutt59. Pours a murky orange with white head. Aroma has some tang, light pumpkin, kinda weak. Flavor has some nice tang, faint pumpkin, some light funkiness. Mouth feel is light body with fizzy carbonation. Overall, a very tasty, interesting beer...........

bottle thanks to decoman.  cloudy light amber with a cream head. spices, light pumpkin and a nice tart overtone. nice on the palate with a spicy pumpkin flavor and a good tart bite in the finish.  age could do this one well.

got the last bottle at champanes  a few weeks ago. poured a golden orange with a very small white head. aroma all the pumpkin spices that you can think of, some sourness that comes with jp beers. flavor the sourness comes out 1st than the spices. jp does another good one
batch 436 thanks to blutt59.  poured hazyish yellow with a white head.  aroma of lemon, tart, earthyness, and brett?.  flavor was lemon, tart, and spicey with a light body.

Bottle at JP Ann Arbor. Poured clear dark orange color with an average off-white frothy head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Solid funky pumpkin aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy pumpkin funky sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate duration. Solid complex seasonal beer.
UPDATED: JAN 6, 2010 bottle batch 436, via trade with ogglethorp,  cloudy golden  pour, aromas of spicy pumpkin and salty ginger?, sour bitter lemon with a chalky texture and some wildflowers
Bottle, batch 436/437 thanks to blutt59. Hazy gold pour. Aroma is funky, band aid and barnyard. Flavor is funk, barnyard, band aid.

Bottle, batch 436/437 thanks to blutt59. Pours with a hazy pumpkin colored body and a white head that stays. Aroma is funky, styrofoam, pumpkin pulp, spice, wood and sourness. Taste is sour, wood, and vegital. Fizzy and dry.

750 ml bottle from Binnys (Orland Park, IL). Excited for this one, and surprised to find it on the shelf! Pours a nice glowing orange, pretty hazy, amber notes with a big frothy white head that laces pretty well. Aromas are subtle pumpkin, cinnamon, and caramel, a bit of fruity banana ester I think, mixed with a tart wild yeast element, a bit funky and warm, vanilla, wild barnyard and straw, a bit fruity. Subtle, but still nice. Initial is subtle, some gentle barnyard funk and light tartness, underneath comes in caramel, vanilla, and pumpkin, light and subtle pie spice and sweetness, light bitterness and earthy hop on the backend, a nice light sourness and funkiness comes up over the top, takes the dominance, a touch of lemon spritz, straw and earthiness. The sweetness is really mellowed out by the wild yeast and wet wood. Light, very drinkable, flavors work very well together. Different than most, one of the best Pumpkin Ales Ive had. Cheers.

Bottle from Rozis in Lakewood.  Pours a medium to dark golden with a three finger white head.  Somewhat sweet aroma with plain pumpkin puree, nutmeg, white apple, and some pleasant sourness.  Flavour is very clean and refreshing, with more pumpkin, bready yeast, pear, and green apple.  The finish is pumpkin pie spice.  This is a very clean and composed brew that I found to be thoroughly enjoyable.
Aroma is slightly funky pumpkins and baking spices.  Flavor is medium tart with pumpkins in the mid-palate and a tart, dry, funky finish slightly reminiscent of electrical fires.

Batch 436/437. Pours a deep orange color with a small to medium sized off white head. Nose is plastic, white pepper, sour pears, and a bit of cocoa.  Taste combines the same elements but is sweeter and a bit earthy. Tangy mouthfeel with a medium to long lingering finish. Nice.

Bottle. Poured a hazy amber orange with a medium thick off-white head. Aroma had clear pumpkin note with a bit of spice. The flavor was odd, but worked nicely with the beer starting with sweet and spicy pumpkin notes, but finished with a earthy sour note.

Golden orange pour with very small tight white head.  Almost no aroma but big immediate flavor.  Definate pumpkin and nutmeg flavor.  But the real backbone of this beer is the traditional jolly pumkin sour earthy flavor.

On draft at the brewpub. Some sour ale like tartness that was good. Not much pumpkin flavor or body. No creaminess here. Brief peppery finish. Some spices, mainly cinnamon, but not enough malts. I was guessing this was more like 4% alc.

25.4 oz bottle.  Clearish pink brown with a lacy white head.  Odd nose, very floral with tulip, cinnamon, nutmeg, lemon and earthy pumpkin.  Medium body with fizzy carb.  Taste is lemon pith, vanilla yoghurt, brief cinnamon and sour apple.  Tartness pushes back the pumpkin with light spices.
